translation1: "Tire choice for racing bikes - really so risk-free? This morning I woke up full of motivation to prepare for my upcoming bike tour, and I at least wanted to train a little bit. Said and done, and I rode my racing bike, which I bought yesterday on eBay.The first 40km were really nice - but then it happened, what lurks in every city center (this time: thanks Krefeld!). Glass shards on the route. Zack, loud hissing and my rear tire refused to participate in the rest of the journey on any account.As I couldn't really get a replacement jacket and inner tube on account of the day of the week, I had to turn around again and take the first train back home with a somewhat bad mood. Then it wasn't technically so bad either, maybe it's even better if I practice the tire change again before the bike tour. But now I'm facing a question and I hope you can help me.As I have a relatively long distance to cover over several days, I would really rather not have this problem often. Now it wasn't too bad, as the old tires from the previous owner (very nice old gentleman, who had ridden 120km on them by the time I picked up the bike) were also described as suboptimal, because he had been riding on them for several years. But if I think about having to replace the tire after 80-90km of riding, I'm afraid I'll be in a really bad mood :DI then got into a conversation with an older man at the platform, who asked me in surprise why I didn't have the Marathon Plus tires; they are supposed to be flat-resistant, don't they? Now the whole thing naturally sounds very tempting. But are they really so indestructible?I have little desire now to spend 40€/tire just to be disappointed in the end. Furthermore, I ask myself: I believe I have 25x622 on my racing bike at the moment, which seems to be available (apparently?) with the Marathon Plus tires, but the majority is already wider.Is this a problem? Or would you advise me to go for other tires on a racing bike in general? The Schwalbe side seems to be my absolute favorite! The experts seem to recommend the Durano DD more?Thank you in advance for the help and kind regards!"
gpt_response: { "Accuracy": { "Mistakes": [ {"Mistake Type": "Omission", "Details": "Omitted detail about not having the chance to acquire a spare tire and tube due to it being a workday."}, {"Mistake Type": "Wrong Translation", "Details": "Mistranslated 'life without popped tires?' as 'really so risk-free?'. This changes the sentiment or tone from hopeful to questioning."}, {"Mistake Type": "Wrong Translation", "Details": "The description of the Schwalbe website opinion was mistranslated as 'The Schwalbe side seems to be my absolute favorite!' instead of 'The Schwalbe website seems to be of one opinion!'."}, {"Mistake Type": "Omission", "Details": "Omitted 'take care!' from the closing."} ]} }
reference: Picking tires for a road bike - life without popped tires? This morning I woke up with a fiery drive because I still wanted to at least train a bit in the upcoming weeks in preparation for my upcoming bicycle tour. It was as easy as that and I drove my road bike which I had bought on eBay the day before. The first 40 km were really beautiful - but then that happened which is always waiting for you in the intercity (this time: thanks goes to Krefeld!). Glass shards on the road. Pop, a loud hiss and my back tire was no longer up for riding the rest of the trip. Because of it being a work day, I didn’t really have the chance to acquire a spare tire and tube, I had to turn back halfway through in a bad mood and take the next workable train back home. It was not the worst downer ever, maybe it is even better if I practice changing tires one more time before I leave to go on the tour. But now I am posed with a question and hope that you will be able to help me. Because I have a relatively long stretch of road and many days in front of me, I would very much like to not run into this problem on a regular basis. This time it really wasn’t that bad, because the tires were from the previous owner (a very nice old man, who had already rode 120 km by 2 PM on the day I came to pick up my bicycle) and because he had described them as suboptimal, because he had already been wearing them down for many years. But if I think about having to change tires every 80-90 km on the tour, then I am already in a really bad mood :D I just got into a discussion with an older man at the train platform, who asked me quite surprised, why I don’t have the Marathon Plus tires, these are supposed to be impossible to pop. Now that certainly does sound tempting. But are they really so indestructible? I have no desire to give out €40 per tire in order to just be disappointed. At the same time, I ask myself: I am using 25x622 race tires at the moment, I believe. This is (apparently?) just like the Marathon Plus tires, but the majority of tires are actually wider. Is that the real problem? Or would you recommend that I really get different tires in general for the road bike? The Schwalbe website seems to be of one opinion! Would common sense tend to recommend the Durano DD? Thank you in advance for your help and take care!

translation1: "\"Party, which we wanted to throw\": Frankfurt celebrates after scoring a comeback against Leverkusen. What a spectacular reaction from Eintracht Frankfurt! After 22 minutes, the Hessians, who had lost their last two games in a row, seemed to be on their way to another Bundesliga defeat.But then the SGE turned it on, got rid of their frustration from a mixed start to the season within an hour, and won furiously with 5:2. \"It's crazy what the guys did today,\" coach Oliver Glasner exclaimed on DAZN and gave a \"blanket praise\" to everyone involved. At first, it looked like another disappointment for Frankfurt, who are still behind their expectations in ninth place. Patrik Schick had put Leverkusen ahead 2:0.What then happened also impressed the SGE coach. \"How the players then came back and showed a fantastic performance\", so Glasner further. I am incredibly happy with the performance we showed and of course also with the result.Even defender Christopher Lenz, who was able to play again for the first time since the fourth game day and overcame his muscle injury, emphasized the morale of his teammates. \"I believe our mentality is incredible,\" said the 27-year-old, looking forward to the result, especially for the spectators. That was the party we wanted to throw today.For the upcoming tasks, Glasner wants to keep the focus within himself, but he is also well-prepared in terms of personnel. It is extraordinary that we have all players fit in December, that all players are physically in top condition. It is top work in our medical department, but the players also live a highly professional lifestyle.No one wanted to \"go step by step and remain humble\" and carry out the tasks until the end of the year \"at this level\". Next up is an away game in English week on Wednesday at Borussia Mönchengladbach (6:30 pm, Sky)."

But then the SGE turned themselves around and were able to shoot the frustration of a poor start to the season out of their soul within an hour, leading to a furious 5-2 victory. “It was crazy what the boys were able to accomplish today,” Coach Oliver Glasner said with jubilee at DAZN and spoke of “praise all around, to each and every one of them who were there”. translation1: "Problems with glass fiber + Devolo DLan/Magic We have had a new glass fiber connection in the house for a few weeks. Unfortunately, I am now having trouble building a stable WiFi network.Before, I had a 50 Mbps DSL connection and used Devolo DLan, which received and transmitted 50 Mbps flawlessly, except for a few failures. The new fiber optic connection sends 500 Mbps to the FritzBox 7590 and at the DLan module attached to the FritzBox, these are also received. reference: I also think that as a general rule, children should not be expected to overtake a parental role for their younger siblings. Sometimes check-up on them, sometimes help, sometimes get the bottle, etc. They learn responsibility this way, help within the family and are thus connected with it. translation1: "Heavy \"Huidlerer\" question: Amberger knows the solution What exactly is a \"Huidlerer\"? Whereupon the man from Amberg provided the solution and thus probably also caused astonishment among many people from the Upper Palatinate. \"The Huidlerer,\" the viewers learned, \"is a rag with which someone wipes the oven.\"Dialect researcher Antony Rowley, who has been consulted as an expert by Bavarian television for years, confirmed this. With the remark that this is a typical Upper Palatinate term, derived somehow from the better-known dialect word \"Houdern\". Thus, a gap in education was closed - probably also for many who have lived in the Amberg area for a long time."
